main event: Unidentified aerial objects were sighted by Japanese and U.S. personnel near the Panama Canal and in Japan in 1950 and 1959.
interesting points: In August 1950, a glowing aerial object was observed by the crew of a German ship traveling northbound on the Panama Canal. The object was described as half the size of the setting sun with a bright glow, and it did not resemble a meteor or cluster of stars.

In August 1959, several Japanese and one U.S. CIC (Counter Intelligence Corps) agent reported sighting unidentified objects that appeared to be flying saucers at an altitude of around 2,000 feet near Niigata, Japan. The objects changed color from yellow to blue to red, separated into two parts, and made a hissing noise before fading out.
The U.S. Air Force received reports of these incidents and classified them as unidentified flying objects for further investigation.
The reports mention that multiple witnesses, including weather station personnel, reported seeing the unidentified objects in both the Panama Canal and Japan incidents.
The objects were described as exhibiting unusual flight characteristics, such as high speed, sudden maneuvers, and disappearing without a trace.
witnesses: Crew of German ship, Japanese and U.S. personnel
